awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Examining Impact and Fostering Academic Support for Open Science Products
awd_abstract_narration:
Open Science has the potential to significantly advance STEM knowledge beyond individual academic research silos. This project will support a conference entitled, "Examining Impact and Fostering Academic Support for Open Science Products." The meeting is jointly organized by the American Educational Research Association (AERA) and the Council of Graduate Schools (CGS).  The objective of the conference is to examine the products of open science practices and explore what counts as productivity and quality in contributions that are non-traditional research outcomes. Non-research outcomes have attendant activities that include data sharing; the development of multi-user data sets, harvesting and archiving big data, replication studies, registered reports, data management plans, and use as well as citation to persistent identifiers (DOIs).

The conference attendees are higher education leaders, education researchers, and related scientists, together with collective expertise in scientific productivity, science professions, higher education institutions.  The conference will engage attendees in a policy conversation and development of performance metrics and assessments on non-traditional research outcomes beyond publication citations in highly ranked journals. This several-day conference, scheduled for Summer 2020, will be held at the AERA Conference Center in Washington DC and will involve about 28 participants. This conference has the potential to support change and foster experimentation in the very institutions where the next generation of researchers are being trained, where science is organized, and where open science products are produced.

This award is co-funded by the NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program. The NRT Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new potentially transformative models for STEM graduate education training.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Purpose

There is little debate that fostering a culture of open knowledge is enabled by a climate of access to information and the underlying data, materials, measurements, and tools of research.  The Open Science paradigm has enormous potential to advance knowledge that is critical to the national interest and societal challenges. Making research materials broadly available promises a higher return on investments in research support.

In October 2019, the American Educational Research Association (AERA) and the Council of Graduate Schools (CSG) launched this project to bring together higher education leaders to discuss the wide spectrum of scholarly processes and products; the incentive and reward structures that motivate (or demotivate) a range of significant work; and especially how productivity, quality, and impact are evaluated in research contributions that are non-traditional (that is, beyond publication citations in highly-ranked journals that do not adequately reflect the quality of the contribution to the field of study).

 

Intellectual Merit

AERA and CSG sought to address the following broad questions:

 

  • How do institutions of higher education (IHE) currently define and measure scientific and scholarly productivity, quality, and impact, and have there been recent changes?

 

  • What processes have the greatest potential to improve the equity, openness, and impact of science and scholarship? What windows of opportunity? and obstacles? do institutions of higher education (IHEs) face?

 

  • How has the COVID-19 pandemic and a period of racial reckoning in the United States supported or created momentum for adopting new conceptions of scientific and scholarly products or processes?

 

  • How can the emerging generation of scientists and scholars?in particular, graduate students and early career researchers? best be prepared for an evolving research enterprise?

 

The team undertook a series of listening sessions at higher education and scientific and scholarly association meetings. The sessions were attended by over 100 scientists and scholars and allowed organizers to more fully understand the disciplinary nuances that affect modes of research, dissemination, and the evaluation of quality and impact. This preliminary inquiry informed the next phase, focus groups.

 

Forty-seven higher education leaders from 15 universities participated in 1 of 4 virtual (Zoom) focus groups, each 3?3.5 hours in length, held in August through October 2021. The universities represented a range of doctoral-granting institutions that are geographically dispersed, including urban and non-urban settings as well as minority-serving institutions. These virtual meetings allowed for data collection during the COVID-19 pandemic. Analysis of memoranda and transcripts from the focus groups led to the development of a working draft report and recommendations for universities and other higher education stakeholders. As in-person meetings resumed in early 2022, these institutions were invited to a Capstone Conference to discuss the draft recommendations and next stages.

The March 24-25, 2022 Capstone Conference provided a vehicle to widen the conversation and engage diverse stakeholders from higher education (including provosts and presidents); scientific, scholarly, and higher education associations; and federal agencies and private foundations. Those assembled discussed the working draft report and other possible recommendations; and considered cross-university collaborations to initiate change, share lessons, and sustain momentum.

 

Outcomes and Broader Impacts

The project produced a successful series of meetings that brought together scientists, university leaders, and other higher education stakeholders to discuss ways to transform the culture and process in which higher education institutions determine what counts as productivity, quality, and impact in science and scholarship, including aligning these with the goals of openness, equity, and inclusion. The meetings included participants from diverse backgrounds, demographics, disciplines, fields of study, and graduate level institutions (including leaders from minority serving institutions).

Over 40 actionable recommendations emerging from the meetings set forth a framework for moving forward the important work of rethinking and realigning incentive and reward structures in universities to enable a more open and inclusive research enterprise.

A final project report, Reimagining Open and Inclusive Science and Scholarship: A Change Agenda for Universities and the Research Enterprise, will be widely disseminated to a range of higher education leaders; scientific, scholarly, and higher education associations; and federal agencies and private foundations.

The published final report and related project information will also be featured on a webpage for broad access.

Other anticipated dissemination activities include an AERA-CSG forum at the AERA Convening Center as well as a symposium and sessions at relevant annual meetings.

The meetings, final report with recommendations, and dissemination activities will prompt further discussions and work within the larger research ecosystem that will facilitate the appreciation of non-traditional research products, methods, and voices in universities? promotion and tenure processes. The work will facilitate cultural change within universities and research communities that will improve how science is conducted, advance knowledge, and ultimately benefit society. The final report and recommendations will also inform NSF's efforts to support open science, data sharing, managing research data, as well as incentive and reward structures in science.
